017package com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.ipt;
018
019import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.FloatColors;
020import com.github.tommyettinger.digital.MathTools;
021import com.github.tommyettinger.digital.TrigTools;
022import com.github.tommyettinger.digital.BitConversion;
023
024import java.util.Random;
025
026/**
027 * Contains code for manipulating colors as {@code int} and packed {@code float} values in the IPT color space.
028 * IPT has more perceptually-uniform handling of hue than some other color spaces, like YCwCm, and even
029 * though the version here gives up the complex exponential adjustments to various components that the original IPT
030 * paper used, it still is pretty good at preserving perceptual lightness. In most regards, this is a more
031 * thoroughly-constructed color space than YCwCm, but YCwCm may still be useful because of how it maps to aesthetic
032 * components of color. See {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)} for docs on the I, P, and T channels.
033 */
034public class ColorTools {
035        /**
036         * Gets a packed float representation of a color given as 4 float components, here, I (intensity or lightness), P
037         * (protan, a chromatic component ranging from greenish to reddish), T (tritan, a chromatic component ranging from
038         * bluish to yellowish), and A (alpha or opacity). Intensity should be between 0 and 1, inclusive, with 0 used for
039         * very dark colors (almost only black), and 1 used for very light colors (almost only white). Protan and tritan
040         * range from 0.0 to 1.0, with grayscale results when both are about 0.5. There's some aesthetic value in changing
041         * just one chroma value. When protan is high and tritan is low, the color is more purple/magenta, when both are low
042         * it is more bluish, when tritan is high and protan is low, the color tends to be greenish, and when both are high
043         * it tends to be orange. When protan and tritan are both near 0.5f, the color is closer to gray.  Alpha is the
044         * multiplicative opacity of the color, and acts like RGBA's alpha.
045         * <br>
046         * This method bit-masks the resulting color's byte values, so any values can technically be given to this as
047         * intensity, protan, and tritan, but they will only be reversible from the returned float color to the original I,
048         * P, and T values if the original values were in the range that {@link #intensity(float)}, {@link #protan(float)},
049         * and {@link #tritan(float)} return.
050         *
051         * @param intens     0f to 1f, intensity or I component of IPT, with 0.5f meaning "no change" and 1f brightening
052         * @param protan     0f to 1f, protan or P component of IPT, with 1f more orange, red, or magenta
053         * @param tritan     0f to 1f, tritan or T component of IPT, with 1f more green, yellow, or red
054         * @param alpha      0f to 1f, 0f makes the color transparent and 1f makes it opaque 
055         * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
056         */
057        public static float ipt(float intens, float protan, float tritan, float alpha) {
058                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (alpha * 255) << 24 & 0xFE000000) | ((int) (tritan * 255) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
059                                | ((int) (protan * 255) << 8 & 0xFF00) | ((int) (intens * 255) & 0xFF));
060        }
061
062        /**
063         * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)} to an RGBA8888 int.
064         * This format of int can be used with Pixmap and in some other places in libGDX.
065         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}
066         * @return an RGBA8888 int color
067         */
068        public static int toRGBA8888(final float packed)
069        {
070                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
071                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
072                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
073                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
074                final int r = Math.min(Math.max((int) ((0.999779f * i + 1.0709400f * p + 0.324891f * t) * 256.0), 0), 255);
075                final int g = Math.min(Math.max((int) ((1.000150f * i - 0.3777440f * p + 0.220439f * t) * 256.0), 0), 255);
076                final int b = Math.min(Math.max((int) ((0.999769f * i + 0.0629496f * p - 0.809638f * t) * 256.0), 0), 255);
077                return r << 24 | g << 16 | b << 8 | (decoded & 0xfe000000) >>> 24 | decoded >>> 31;
078        }
079
080        /**
081         * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}
082         * to a packed float in RGBA format.
083         * This format of float can be used with the standard SpriteBatch and in some other places in libGDX.
084         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}
085         * @return a packed float color as RGBA
086         */
087        public static float toRGBA(final float packed)
088        {
089                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
090                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
091                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
092                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
093                final int r = Math.min(Math.max((int) ((0.999779f * i + 1.0709400f * p + 0.324891f * t) * 256.0), 0), 255);
094                final int g = Math.min(Math.max((int) ((1.000150f * i - 0.3777440f * p + 0.220439f * t) * 256.0), 0), 255);
095                final int b = Math.min(Math.max((int) ((0.999769f * i + 0.0629496f * p - 0.809638f * t) * 256.0), 0), 255);
096                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(r | g << 8 | b << 16 | (decoded & 0xfe000000));
097        }
098
099        /**
100         * Takes a color encoded as an RGBA8888 int and converts to a packed float in the IPT format this uses.
101         * @param rgba an int with the channels (in order) red, green, blue, alpha; should have 8 bits per channel
102         * @return a packed float as IPT, which this class can use
103         */
104        public static float fromRGBA8888(final int rgba) {
105                final float r = (rgba >>> 24) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f;
106                final float g = (rgba >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f;
107                final float b = (rgba >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f;
108                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
109                                      Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.189786f * r + 0.576951f * g + 0.233221f * b) * 255.0f + 0.500f), 0), 255)
110                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.669665f * r - 0.73741f * g + 0.0681367f * b) * 127.5f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
111                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.286498f * r + 0.655205f * g - 0.941748f * b) * 127.5f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
112                                                | (rgba & 0xFE) << 24);
113        }
114
115        /**
116         * Takes a color encoded as an RGBA8888 packed float and converts to a packed float in the IPT format this uses.
117         * @param packed a packed float in RGBA8888 format, with A in the MSB and R in the LSB
118         * @return a packed float as IPT, which this class can use
119         */
120        public static float fromRGBA(final float packed) {
121                final int abgr = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
122                final float r = (abgr & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f;
123                final float g = (abgr >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f;
124                final float b = (abgr >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f;
125
126                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
127                                          Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.189786f * r + 0.576951f * g + 0.233221f * b) * 255.999f), 0), 255)
128                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.669665f * r - 0.73741f * g + 0.0681367f * b) * 127.5f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
129                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.286498f * r + 0.655205f * g - 0.941748f * b) * 127.5f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
130                                                | (abgr & 0xFE000000));
131        }
132
133        /**
134         * Takes RGBA components from 0.0 to 1.0 each and converts to a packed float in the IPT format this uses.
135         * @param r red, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
136         * @param g green, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
137         * @param b blue, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
138         * @param a alpha, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
139         * @return a packed float as IPT, which this class can use
140         */
141        public static float fromRGBA(final float r, final float g, final float b, final float a) {
142                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
143                                          Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.189786f * r + 0.576951f * g + 0.233221f * b) * 255.0f + 0.500f), 0), 255)
144                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.669665f * r - 0.73741f * g + 0.0681367f * b) * 127.5f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
145                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.286498f * r + 0.655205f * g - 0.941748f * b) * 127.5f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
146                                                | ((int)(a * 255f) << 24 & 0xFE000000));
147        }
148
149        /**
150         * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
151         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
152         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
153         */
154        public static int redInt(final float encoded)
155        {
156                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
157                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
158                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
159                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
160                return Math.min(Math.max((int) ((0.999779f * i + 1.0709400f * p + 0.324891f * t) * 256.0), 0), 255);
161        }
162
163        /**
164         * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
165         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
166         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
167         */
168        public static int greenInt(final float encoded)
169        {
170                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
171                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
172                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
173                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
174                return Math.min(Math.max((int) ((1.000150f * i - 0.3777440f * p + 0.220439f * t) * 256.0), 0), 255);
175        }
176
177        /**
178         * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
179         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
180         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
181         */
182        public static int blueInt(final float encoded)
183        {
184                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
185                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
186                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
187                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
188                return Math.min(Math.max((int) ((0.999769f * i + 0.0629496f * p - 0.809638f * t) * 256.0), 0), 255);
189        }
190
191        /**
192         * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as an even int ranging from 0 to 254, inclusive. Because
193         * of how alpha is stored in libGDX, no odd-number values are possible for alpha.
194         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
195         * @return an even int from 0 to 254, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
196         */
197        public static int alphaInt(final float encoded)
198        {
199                return (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24;
200        }
201
202        /**
203         * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
204         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
205         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
206         */
207        public static float red(final float encoded)
208        {
209                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
210                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
211                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
212                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
213                return Math.min(Math.max((0.999779f * i + 1.0709400f * p + 0.324891f * t), 0f), 1f);
214        }
215
216        /**
217         * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
218         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
219         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
220         */
221        public static float green(final float encoded)
222        {
223                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
224                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
225                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
226                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
227                return Math.min(Math.max((1.000150f * i - 0.3777440f * p + 0.220439f * t), 0f), 1f);
228        }
229
230        /**
231         * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
232         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
233         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
234         */
235        public static float blue(final float encoded)
236        {
237                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
238                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
239                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
240                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
241                return Math.min(Math.max((0.999769f * i + 0.0629496f * p - 0.809638f * t), 0f), 1f);
242        }
243
244        /**
245         * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
246         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
247         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
248         */
249        public static float alpha(final float encoded)
250        {
251                return ((BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24) * 0x1.020408p-8f;
252        }
253
254        /**
255         * Gets a color as an IPT packed float given floats representing hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity.
256         * All parameters should normally be between 0 and 1 inclusive, though any hue is tolerated (precision loss may
257         * affect the color if the hue is too large). A hue of 0 is red, progressively higher hue values go to orange,
258         * yellow, green, blue, and purple before wrapping around to red as it approaches 1. A saturation of 0 is grayscale,
259         * a saturation of 1 is brightly colored, and values close to 1 will usually appear more distinct than values close
260         * to 0, especially if the hue is different. A lightness of 0.001f or less is always black (also using a shortcut if
261         * this is the case, respecting opacity), while a lightness of 1f is white. Very bright colors are mostly in a band
262         * of high-saturation where lightness is 0.5f.
263         *
264         * @param hue        0f to 1f, color wheel position
265         * @param saturation 0f to 1f, 0f is grayscale and 1f is brightly colored
266         * @param lightness  0f to 1f, 0f is black and 1f is white
267         * @param opacity    0f to 1f, 0f is fully transparent and 1f is opaque
268         * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
269         */
270        public static float floatGetHSL(float hue, float saturation, float lightness, float opacity) {
271                if (lightness <= 0.001f) {
272                        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x7F7F00);
273                } else {
274                        return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue, saturation, lightness, opacity));
275                }
276        }
277
278        /**
279         * Gets the saturation of the given encoded color, as a float ranging from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
280         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
281         * @return the saturation of the color from 0.0 (a grayscale color; inclusive) to 1.0 (a bright color, inclusive)
282         */
283        public static float saturation(final float encoded) {
284                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
285                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
286                if(Math.abs(i - 0.5) > 0.495f) return 0f;
287                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
288                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
289                final float r = Math.min(Math.max((0.999779f * i + 1.0709400f * p + 0.324891f * t), 0f), 1f);
290                final float g = Math.min(Math.max((1.000150f * i - 0.3777440f * p + 0.220439f * t), 0f), 1f);
291                final float b = Math.min(Math.max((0.999769f * i + 0.0629496f * p - 0.809638f * t), 0f), 1f);
292                float x, y, w;
293                if(g < b) {
294                        x = b;
295                        y = g;
296                }
297                else {
298                        x = g;
299                        y = b;
300                }
301                if(r < x) {
302                        w = r;
303                }
304                else {
305                        w = x;
306                        x = r;
307                }
308                return x - Math.min(w, y);
309//              float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
310//              float li = x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
311//              return (x - li); // (Math.min(li, 1f - li) + 1e-10f);
312        }
313
314        public static float lightness(final float encoded) {
315                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
316                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
317                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
318                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
319                final float r = Math.min(Math.max((0.999779f * i + 1.0709400f * p + 0.324891f * t), 0f), 1f);
320                final float g = Math.min(Math.max((1.000150f * i - 0.3777440f * p + 0.220439f * t), 0f), 1f);
321                final float b = Math.min(Math.max((0.999769f * i + 0.0629496f * p - 0.809638f * t), 0f), 1f);
322
323                float x, y, w;
324                if(g < b) {
325                        x = b;
326                        y = g;
327                }
328                else {
329                        x = g;
330                        y = b;
331                }
332                if(r < x) {
333                        w = r;
334                }
335                else {
336                        w = x;
337                        x = r;
338                }
339                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
340                return x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
341        }
342
343        /**
344         * Gets the hue of the given encoded color, as a float from 0f (inclusive, red and approaching orange if increased)
345         * to 1f (exclusive, red and approaching purple if decreased).
346         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
347         * @return The hue of the color from 0.0 (red, inclusive) towards orange, then yellow, and
348         * eventually to purple before looping back to almost the same red (1.0, exclusive)
349         */
350        public static float hue(final float encoded) {
351                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
352                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
353                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
354                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
355                final float r = Math.min(Math.max((0.999779f * i + 1.0709400f * p + 0.324891f * t), 0f), 1f);
356                final float g = Math.min(Math.max((1.000150f * i - 0.3777440f * p + 0.220439f * t), 0f), 1f);
357                final float b = Math.min(Math.max((0.999769f * i + 0.0629496f * p - 0.809638f * t), 0f), 1f);
358                float x, y, z, w;
359                if(g < b) {
360                        x = b;
361                        y = g;
362                        z = -1f;
363                        w = 2f / 3f;
364                }
365                else {
366                        x = g;
367                        y = b;
368                        z = 0f;
369                        w = -1f / 3f;
370                }
371                if(r < x) {
372                        z = w;
373                        w = r;
374                }
375                else {
376                        w = x;
377                        x = r;
378                }
379                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
380                return Math.abs(z + (w - y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f));
381        }
382
383        /**
384         * The "intensity" of the given packed float in IPT format, which is like its lightness; ranges from 0.0f to
385         * 1.0f . You can edit the intensity of a color with {@link #lighten(float, float)} and
386         * {@link #darken(float, float)}.
387         *
388         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
389         * @return the intensity value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
390         */
391        public static float intensity(final float encoded)
392        {
393                return (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xff) / 255f;
394        }
395
396        /**
397         * The "protan" of the given packed float in IPT format, which when combined with tritan describes the
398         * hue and saturation of a color; ranges from 0f to 1f . If protan is 0f, the color will be cooler, more green or
399         * blue; if protan is 1f, the color will be warmer, from magenta to orange. You can edit the protan of a color with
400         * {@link #protanUp(float, float)} and {@link #protanDown(float, float)}.
401         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
402         * @return the protan value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
403         */
404        public static float protan(final float encoded)
405        {
406                return ((BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 8 & 0xff)) / 255f;
407        }
408
409        /**
410         * The "tritan" of the given packed float in IPT format, which when combined with protan describes the
411         * hue and saturation of a color; ranges from 0f to 1f . If tritan is 0f, the color will be more "artificial", more
412         * blue or purple; if tritan is 1f, the color will be more "natural", from green to yellow to orange. You can edit
413         * the tritan of a color with {@link #tritanUp(float, float)} and {@link #tritanDown(float, float)}.
414         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
415         * @return the tritan value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
416         */
417        public static float tritan(final float encoded)
418        {
419                return ((BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 16 & 0xff)) / 255f;
420        }
421
422        /**
423         * Gets a variation on the packed float color basis as another packed float that has its hue, saturation, lightness,
424         * and opacity adjusted by the specified amounts. Note that this edits the color in HSL space, not IPT! Takes
425         * floats representing the amounts of change to apply to hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity; these can be
426         * between -1f and 1f. Returns a float that can be used as a packed or encoded color. The float is
427         * likely to be different than the result of {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)} unless hue, saturation,
428         * lightness, and opacity are all 0. This won't allocate any objects.
429         * <br>
430         * The parameters this takes all specify additive changes for a color component, clamping the final values so they
431         * can't go above 1 or below 0, with an exception for hue, which can rotate around if lower or higher hues would be
432         * used. As an example, if you give this 0.4f for saturation, and the current color has saturation 0.7f, then the
433         * resulting color will have 1f for saturation. If you gave this -0.1f for saturation and the current color again
434         * has saturation 0.7f, then resulting color will have 0.6f for saturation.
435         *
436         * @param basis      a packed float color that will be used as the starting point to make the next color
437         * @param hue        -1f to 1f, the hue change that can be applied to the new float color (not clamped, wraps)
438         * @param saturation -1f to 1f, the saturation change that can be applied to the new float color
439         * @param light      -1f to 1f, the light/brightness change that can be applied to the new float color
440         * @param opacity    -1f to 1f, the opacity/alpha change that can be applied to the new float color
441         * @return a float encoding a variation of basis with the given changes
442         */
443        public static float toEditedFloat(float basis, float hue, float saturation, float light, float opacity) {
444                final int e = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(basis);
445                final float i = Math.min(Math.max(light + (e & 0xff) / 255f, 0f), 1f);
446                opacity = Math.min(Math.max(opacity + (e >>> 24 & 0xfe) * 0x1.020408p-8f, 0f), 1f);
447                if (i <= 0.001f)
448                        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x808000);
449                final float p = ((e >>> 7 & 0x1fe) - 0xff) / 255f;
450                final float t = ((e >>> 15 & 0x1fe) - 0xff) / 255f;
451                final float r = Math.min(Math.max((0.999779f * i + 1.0709400f * p + 0.324891f * t), 0f), 1f);
452                final float g = Math.min(Math.max((1.000150f * i - 0.3777440f * p + 0.220439f * t), 0f), 1f);
453                final float b = Math.min(Math.max((0.999769f * i + 0.0629496f * p - 0.809638f * t), 0f), 1f);
454                float x, y, z, w;
455                if(g < b) {
456                        x = b;
457                        y = g;
458                        z = -1f;
459                        w = 2f / 3f;
460                }
461                else {
462                        x = g;
463                        y = b;
464                        z = 0f;
465                        w = -1f / 3f;
466                }
467                if(r < x) {
468                        z = w;
469                        w = r;
470                }
471                else {
472                        w = x;
473                        x = r;
474                }
475                final float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
476                final float lum = x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
477                hue += Math.abs(z + (w - y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f)) + 1f;
478                saturation += (x - lum) / (Math.min(lum, 1f - lum) + 1e-10f);
479                return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue - (int)hue, Math.min(Math.max(saturation, 0f), 1f), lum, opacity));
480        }
481
482        /**
483         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards white by change. While change should be between 0f (return
484         * start as-is) and 1f (return white), start should be a packed color, as from
485         * {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
486         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
487         * white. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both chroma of start as-is.
488         * @see #darken(float, float) the counterpart method that darkens a float color
489         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
490         * @param change how much to go from start toward white, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to white
491         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and white
492         */
493        public static float lighten(final float start, final float change) {
494                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), i = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
495                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (i + (0xFF - i) * change) & 0xFF) | other);
496        }
497
498        /**
499         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards black by change. While change should be between 0f (return
500         * start as-is) and 1f (return black), start should be a packed color, as from
501         * {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
502         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
503         * black. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both chroma of start as-is.
504         * @see #lighten(float, float) the counterpart method that lightens a float color
505         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
506         * @param change how much to go from start toward black, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to black
507         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and black
508         */
509        public static float darken(final float start, final float change) {
510                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), i = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
511                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (i * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) | other);
512        }
513
514        /**
515         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a warmer color (orange to magenta) by change. While change
516         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully warmed), start should be a packed color, as from
517         * {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
518         * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to
519         * lerp towards a warmer color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the
520         * alpha and intensity of start as-is.
521         * @see #protanDown(float, float) the counterpart method that cools a float color
522         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
523         * @param change how much to warm start, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a warmer result
524         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a warmer color
525         */
526        public static float protanUp(final float start, final float change) {
527                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), p = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
528                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (p + (0xFF - p) * change) << 8 & 0xFF00) | other);
529        }
530
531        /**
532         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a cooler color (green to blue) by change. While change
533         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully cooled), start should be a packed color, as from
534         * {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
535         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
536         * towards a cooler color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and
537         * intensity of start as-is.
538         * @see #protanUp(float, float) the counterpart method that warms a float color
539         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
540         * @param change how much to cool start, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a cooler result
541         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a cooler color
542         */
543        public static float protanDown(final float start, final float change) {
544                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), p = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
545                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (p * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 8 | other);
546        }
547
548        /**
549         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a "natural" color (between green and orange) by change.
550         * While change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully natural), start should be a packed color, as
551         * from {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
552         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using
553         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards a more natural color. Unlike
554         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and intensity of start as-is.
555         * @see #tritanDown(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less natural
556         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
557         * @param change how much to change start to a natural color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more natural result
558         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a more natural color
559         */
560        public static float tritanUp(final float start, final float change) {
561                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
562                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t + (0xFF - t) * change) << 16 & 0xFF0000) | other);
563        }
564
565        /**
566         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards an "artificial" color (between blue and purple) by change.
567         * While change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully artificial), start should be a packed color, as
568         * from {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
569         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
570         * towards a more artificial color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the
571         * alpha and intensity of start as-is.
572         * @see #tritanUp(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less artificial
573         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
574         * @param change how much to change start to a bolder color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more artificial result
575         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a more artificial color
576         */
577        public static float tritanDown(final float start, final float change) {
578                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
579                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 16 | other);
580        }
581
582        /**
583         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards that color made opaque by change. While change should be
584         * between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return start with full alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
585         * {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
586         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
587         * transparent. This won't change the intensity, protan, or tritan of the color.
588         * @see #fade(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more translucent
589         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
590         * @param change how much to go from start toward opaque, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to opaque
591         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and its opaque version
592         */
593        public static float blot(final float start, final float change) {
594                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s >>> 24 & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
595                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity + (0xFE - opacity) * change) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
596        }
597
598        /**
599         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards transparent by change. While change should be between 0
600         * (return start as-is) and 1f (return the color with 0 alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
601         * {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
602         * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
603         * transparent. This won't change the intensity, protan, or tritan of the color.
604         * @see #blot(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more opaque
605         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
606         * @param change how much to go from start toward transparent, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to transparent
607         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and transparent
608         */
609        public static float fade(final float start, final float change) {
610                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
611                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity * (1f - change)) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
612        }
613
614        /**
615         * Brings the chromatic components of {@code start} closer to grayscale by {@code change} (desaturating them). While
616         * change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully gray), start should be a packed color, as
617         * from {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This only changes protan and tritan; it leaves intensity and alpha
618         * alone, unlike {@link #lessenChange(float, float)}, which usually changes intensity.
619         * @see #enrich(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more saturated
620         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
621         * @param change how much to change start to a desaturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a less saturated result
622         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a desaturated color
623         */
624        public static float dullen(final float start, final float change) {
625                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start);
626                return ipt((s & 0xFF) / 255f,
627                                ((s >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f - change) + 0.5f,
628                                ((s >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f - change) + 0.5f,
629                                (s >>> 25) / 127f);
630        }
631
632        /**
633         * Pushes the chromatic components of {@code start} away from grayscale by change (saturating them). While change
634         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return maximally saturated), start should be a packed color, as
635         * from {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This usually changes only protan and tritan, but higher values for
636         * {@code change} can force the color out of the gamut, which this corrects using
637         * {@link #limitToGamut(float, float, float, float)} (and that can change intensity somewhat). If the color stays
638         * in-gamut, then intensity won't change; alpha never changes.
639         * @see #dullen(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less saturated
640         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
641         * @param change how much to change start to a saturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more saturated result
642         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a saturated color
643         */
644        public static float enrich(final float start, final float change) {
645                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start);
646                return limitToGamut((s & 0xFF) / 255f,
647                                ((s >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f + change) + 0.5f,
648                                ((s >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f + change) + 0.5f,
649                                (s >>> 25) / 127f);
650        }
651
652        /**
653         * Given a packed float IPT color {@code mainColor} and another IPT color that it should be made to contrast with,
654         * gets a packed float IPT color with roughly inverted intnsity but the same chromatic channels and opacity (P and T
655         * are likely to be clamped if the result gets close to white or black). This won't ever produce black or other very
656         * dark colors, and also has a gap in the range it produces for intensity values between 0.5 and 0.55. That allows
657         * most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on a background of
658         * {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa. This will leave the intensity unchanged if the chromatic channels of the
659         * contrastingColor and those of the mainColor are already very different. This has nothing to do with the contrast
660         * channel of the tweak in ColorfulBatch; where that part of the tweak can make too-similar lightness values further
661         * apart by just a little, this makes a modification on {@code mainColor} to maximize its lightness difference from
662         * {@code contrastingColor} without losing its other qualities.
663         * @param mainColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}; this is the color that will be adjusted
664         * @param contrastingColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}; the adjusted mainColor will contrast with this
665         * @return a different IPT packed float color, based on mainColor but with potentially very different lightness
666         */
667        public static float inverseLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
668        {
669                final int bits = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor),
670                                contrastBits = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor),
671                                i = (bits & 0xff),
672                                p = (bits >>> 8 & 0xff),
673                                t = (bits >>> 16 & 0xff),
674                                ci = (contrastBits & 0xff),
675                                cp = (contrastBits >>> 8 & 0xff),
676                                ct = (contrastBits >>> 16 & 0xff);
677                if((p - cp) * (p - cp) + (t - ct) * (t - ct) >= 0x10000)
678                        return mainColor;
679                return ipt(ci < 128 ? i * (0.45f / 255f) + 0.55f : 0.5f - i * (0.45f / 255f), p / 255f, t / 255f, 0x1.0p-8f * (bits >>> 24));
680        }
681
682        /**
683         * Given a packed float IPT color {@code mainColor} and another IPT color that it should be made to contrast
684         * with, gets a packed float IPT color with I that should be quite different from {@code contrastingColor}'s I,
685         * but the same chromatic channels and opacity (A and B are likely to be clamped if the result gets close to white
686         * or black). This allows most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on
687         * a background of {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa.
688         * <br>
689         * This is similar to {@link #inverseLightness(float, float)}, but is considerably simpler, and this method will
690         * change the lightness of mainColor when the two given colors have close lightness but distant chroma. Because it
691         * averages the original I of mainColor with the modified one, this tends to not produce harsh color changes.
692         * @param mainColor a packed IPT float color; this is the color that will be adjusted
693         * @param contrastingColor a packed IPT float color; the adjusted mainColor will contrast with the I of this
694         * @return a different packed IPT float color, based on mainColor but typically with different lightness
695         */
696        public static float differentiateLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
697        {
698                final int main = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor), contrast = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor);
699                return limitToGamut(BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((main & 0xFEFFFF00) | (contrast + 128 & 0xFF) + (main & 0xFF) >>> 1));
700        }
701
702        /**
703         * Pretty simple; adds 0.5 to the given color's I and wraps it around if it would go above 1.0, then averages that
704         * with the original I. This means light colors become darker, and dark colors become lighter, with almost all
705         * results in the middle-range of possible lightness.
706         * @param mainColor a packed IPT float color
707         * @return a different packed IPT float color, with its I channel changed and limited to the correct gamut
708         */
709        public static float offsetLightness(final float mainColor) {
710                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor);
711                return limitToGamut(BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((decoded & 0xFEFFFF00) | (decoded + 128 & 0xFF) + (decoded & 0xFF) >>> 1));
712        }
713
714        /**
715         * Makes the additive IPT color stored in {@code color} cause less of a change when used as a tint, as if it were
716         * mixed with neutral gray. When {@code fraction} is 1.0, this returns color unchanged; when fraction is 0.0, it
717         * returns {@link Palette#GRAY}, and when it is in-between 0.0 and 1.0 it returns something between the two. This is
718         * meant for things like area of effect abilities that make smaller color changes toward their periphery.
719         * @param color a color that should have its tinting effect potentially weakened
720         * @param fraction how much of {@code color} should be kept, from 0.0 to 1.0
721         * @return an IPT float color between gray and {@code color}
722         */
723        public static float lessenChange(final float color, float fraction) {
724                final int e = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(color),
725                                is = 0x80, ps = 0x80, ts = 0x80,
726                                ie = (e & 0xFF), pe = (e >>> 8) & 0xFF, te = (e >>> 16) & 0xFF, ae = e >>> 24 & 0xFE;
727                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (is + fraction * (ie - is)) & 0xFF)
728                                | (((int) (ps + fraction * (pe - ps)) & 0xFF) << 8)
729                                | (((int) (ts + fraction * (te - ts)) & 0xFF) << 16)
730                                | (ae << 24));
731        }
732
733        /**
734         * Makes a quasi-randomly-edited variant on the given {@code color}, allowing typically a small amount of
735         * {@code variance} (such as 0.05 to 0.25) between the given color and what this can return. The {@code seed} should
736         * be different each time this is called, and can be obtained from a random number generator to make the colors more
737         * random, or can be incremented on each call. If the seed is only incremented or decremented, then this shouldn't
738         * produce two similar colors in a row unless variance is very small. The variance affects the I, P, and T of the
739         * generated color, and each of those channels can go up or down by the given variance as long as the total distance
740         * isn't greater than the variance (this considers P and T extra-wide, going from -1 to 1, while I goes from 0 to 1,
741         * but only internally for measuring distance).
742         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
743         * @param seed a long seed that should be different on each call; should not be 0
744         * @param variance max amount of difference between the given color and the generated color; always less than 1
745         * @return a generated packed float color that should be at least somewhat different from {@code color}
746         */
747        public static float randomEdit(final float color, long seed, final float variance) {
748                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(color);
749                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
750                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
751                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
752                final float limit = variance * variance;
753                float dist, x, y, z;
754                for (int j = 0; j < 50; j++) {
755                        x = (((seed * 0xD1B54A32D192ED03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
756                        y = (((seed * 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
757                        z = (((seed * 0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
758                        seed += 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L;
759                        dist = x * x + y * y + z * z;
760                        if(dist <= limit && inGamut(x += i, y = (p + y) * 0.5f + 0.5f, z = (t + z) * 0.5f + 0.5f))
761                                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((decoded & 0xFE000000) | ((int)(z * 255.5f) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
762                                        | ((int)(y * 255.5f) << 8 & 0xFF00) | (int)(x * 255.5f));
763                }
764                return color;
765        }
766
767        /**
768         * Returns true if the given packed float color, as IPT, is valid to convert losslessly back to RGBA. 
769         * @param packed a packed float color as IPT
770         * @return true if the given packed float color can be converted back and forth to RGBA
771         */
772        public static boolean inGamut(final float packed)
773        {
774                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
775                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
776                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
777                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
778                final float r = 0.999779f * i + 1.0709400f * p + 0.324891f * t;
779                if(r < -0.006f || r > 1.003f) return false;
780                final float g = 1.000150f * i - 0.3777440f * p + 0.220439f * t;
781                if(g < -0.006f || g > 1.003f)
782                        return false;
783                final float b = 0.999769f * i + 0.0629496f * p - 0.809638f * t;
784                return (b >= -0.006f && b <= 1.003f);
785        }
786        /**
787         * Returns true if the given IPT values are valid to convert losslessly back to RGBA. 
788         * @param i intensity channel, as a float from 0 to 1
789         * @param p protan channel, as a float from 0 to 1
790         * @param t tritan channel, as a float from 0 to 1
791         * @return true if the given packed float color can be converted back and forth to RGBA
792         */
793        public static boolean inGamut(float i, float p, float t)
794        {
795                p = (p - 0.5f) * 2f;
796                t = (t - 0.5f) * 2f;
797                final float r = 0.999779f * i + 1.0709400f * p + 0.324891f * t;
798                if(r < -0.006f || r > 1.003f) return false;
799                final float g = 1.000150f * i - 0.3777440f * p + 0.220439f * t;
800                if(g < -0.006f || g > 1.003f)
801                        return false;
802                final float b = 0.999769f * i + 0.0629496f * p - 0.809638f * t;
803                return (b >= -0.006f && b <= 1.003f);
804        }
805
806        /**
807         * Iteratively checks whether the given IPT color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to 50% gray if it
808         * isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut.
809         * @param packed a packed float color in IPT format; often this color is not in-gamut
810         * @return the first color this finds that is between the given IPT color and 50% gray, and is in-gamut
811         * @see #inGamut(float) You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
812         */
813        public static float limitToGamut(final float packed) {
814                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
815                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
816                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
817                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
818                float i2 = i, p2 = p, t2 = t;
819                for (int attempt = 31; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
820                        final float r = 0.999779f * i2 + 1.0709400f * p2 + 0.324891f * t2;
821                        final float g = 1.000150f * i2 - 0.3777440f * p2 + 0.220439f * t2;
822                        final float b = 0.999769f * i2 + 0.0629496f * p2 - 0.809638f * t2;
823                        if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
824                                break;
825                        final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-5f;
826                        i2 = MathTools.lerp(0.5f, i, progress);
827                        p2 = MathTools.lerp(0, p, progress);
828                        t2 = MathTools.lerp(0, t, progress);
829                }
830                return ipt(i2, p2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, t2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, (decoded >>> 25) / 127f);
831        }
832
833        /**
834         * Iteratively checks whether the given IPT color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to 50% gray if it
835         * isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut. This always produces an opaque color.
836         * @param i intensity component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
837         * @param p protan component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
838         * @param t tritan component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
839         * @return the first color this finds that is between the given IPT color and 50% gray, and is in-gamut
840         * @see #inGamut(float, float, float)  You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
841         */
842        public static float limitToGamut(float i, float p, float t) {
843                return limitToGamut(i, p, t, 1f);
844        }
845        /**
846         * Iteratively checks whether the given IPT color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to 50% gray if it
847         * isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut.
848         * @param i intensity component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
849         * @param p protan component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
850         * @param t tritan component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
851         * @param a alpha component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
852         * @return the first color this finds that is between the given IPT color and 50% gray, and is in-gamut
853         * @see #inGamut(float, float, float)  You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
854         */
855        public static float limitToGamut(float i, float p, float t, float a) {
856                float i2 = i = Math.min(Math.max(i, 0f), 1f);
857                float p2 = p = Math.min(Math.max((p - 0.5f) * 2f, -1f), 1f);
858                float t2 = t = Math.min(Math.max((t - 0.5f) * 2f, -1f), 1f);
859                a = Math.min(Math.max(a, 0f), 1f);
860                for (int attempt = 31; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
861                        final float r = 0.999779f * i2 + 1.0709400f * p2 + 0.324891f * t2;
862                        final float g = 1.000150f * i2 - 0.3777440f * p2 + 0.220439f * t2;
863                        final float b = 0.999769f * i2 + 0.0629496f * p2 - 0.809638f * t2;
864                        if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
865                                break;
866                        final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-5f;
867                        i2 = MathTools.lerp(0.5f, i, progress);
868                        p2 = MathTools.lerp(0, p, progress);
869                        t2 = MathTools.lerp(0, t, progress);
870                }
871                return ipt(i2, p2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, t2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, a);
872        }
873        /**
874         * Given a packed float IPT color, this edits its intensity, protan, tritan, and alpha channels by adding the
875         * corresponding "add" parameter and then clamping. This returns a different float value (of course, the given float
876         * can't be edited in-place). You can give a value of 0 for any "add" parameter you want to stay unchanged. This
877         * clamps the resulting color to remain in-gamut, so it should be safe to convert it back to RGBA.
878         * @param encoded a packed float IPT color
879         * @param addI how much to add to the intensity channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
880         * @param addP how much to add to the protan channel; typically in the -2 to 2 range
881         * @param addT how much to add to the tritan channel; typically in the -2 to 2 range
882         * @param addAlpha how much to add to the alpha channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
883         * @return a packed float IPT color with the requested edits applied to {@code encoded}
884         */
885        public static float editIPT(float encoded, float addI, float addP, float addT, float addAlpha) {
886                return editIPT(encoded, addI, addP, addT, addAlpha, 1f, 1f, 1f, 1f);
887        }
888        /**
889         * Given a packed float IPT color, this edits its intensity, protan, tritan, and alpha channels by first
890         * multiplying each channel by the corresponding "mul" parameter and then adding the corresponding "add" parameter,
891         * before clamping. This means the intensity value is multiplied by {@code mulI}, then has {@code addI} added, and
892         * then is clamped to the normal range for intensity (0 to 1). This returns a different float value (of course, the
893         * given float can't be edited in-place). You can give a value of 0 for any "add" parameter you want to stay
894         * unchanged, or a value of 1 for any "mul" parameter that shouldn't change. Note that this manipulates protan and
895         * tritan in the -1 to 1 range, so if you multiply by a small number like {@code 0.25f}, then this will produce a
896         * less-saturated color, and if you multiply by a larger number like {@code 4f}, then you will get a much
897         * more-saturated color. This clamps the resulting color to remain in-gamut, so it should be safe to convert it back
898         * to RGBA.
899         * @param encoded a packed float IPT color
900         * @param addI how much to add to the intensity channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
901         * @param addP how much to add to the protan channel; typically in the -2 to 2 range
902         * @param addT how much to add to the tritan channel; typically in the -2 to 2 range
903         * @param addAlpha how much to add to the alpha channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
904         * @param mulI how much to multiply the intensity channel by; should be non-negative
905         * @param mulP how much to multiply the protan channel by; usually non-negative (not always)
906         * @param mulT how much to multiply the tritan channel by; usually non-negative (not always)
907         * @param mulAlpha how much to multiply the alpha channel by; should be non-negative
908         * @return a packed float IPT color with the requested edits applied to {@code encoded}
909         */
910        public static float editIPT(float encoded, float addI, float addP, float addT, float addAlpha,
911                                                                float mulI, float mulP, float mulT, float mulAlpha) {
912                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
913                float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
914                float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
915                float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
916                float alpha = (decoded >>> 25) / 127f;
917
918                float i2 = Math.min(Math.max(i * mulI + addI, 0f), 1f);
919                float p2 = p = Math.min(Math.max(p * mulP + addP, -1f), 1f);
920                float t2 = t = Math.min(Math.max(t * mulT + addT, -1f), 1f);
921                alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha * mulAlpha + addAlpha, 0f), 1f);
922                for (int attempt = 31; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
923                        final float r = 0.999779f * i2 + 1.0709400f * p2 + 0.324891f * t2;
924                        final float g = 1.000150f * i2 - 0.3777440f * p2 + 0.220439f * t2;
925                        final float b = 0.999769f * i2 + 0.0629496f * p2 - 0.809638f * t2;
926                        if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
927                                break;
928                        final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-5f;
929                        p2 = MathTools.lerp(0, p, progress);
930                        t2 = MathTools.lerp(0, t, progress);
931                }
932                return ipt(i2, p2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, t2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, alpha);
933        }
934
935        /**
936         * Converts from a packed float in HSI format to a packed float in IPT format.
937         * @param packed a packed float in HSI format
938         * @return a packed float in IPT format
939         */
940        public static float fromHSI(float packed){
941                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
942                final float h = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
943                final float s = (decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) / 255f;
944                final float i = (decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) / 255f;
945                final float y = TrigTools.cosTurns(h) * s, z = TrigTools.sinTurns(h) * s;
946                final float crMid = 0.3481738f * y + 0.104959644f * z;
947                final float crScale = (i - 0.5f + (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(crMid) >>> 31)) * 0.16420607f / -crMid;
948                final float mgMid = 0.122068435f * y + -0.070396f * z;
949                final float mgScale = (i + 0.5f - (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mgMid) >>> 31)) * -0.16136102f / -mgMid;
950                final float ybMid = 0.020876605f * y + -0.26078433f * z;
951                final float ybScale = (i - 0.5f + (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(ybMid) >>> 31)) * 0.16155326f / -ybMid;
952                final float scale = Math.max(crScale, Math.max(mgScale, ybScale));
953                final float d = 4f * s * scale / (TrigTools.sin(3.14159f * i) + 0.000001f);
954
955                final float p = y * d;
956                final float t = z * d;
957                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((decoded & 0xFE000000) | ((int) (t * 255) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
958                                | ((int) (p * 255) << 8 & 0xFF00) | (decoded >>> 16 & 0xFF));
959        }
960
961        /**
962         * Converts from hue, saturation, intensity, and alpha components (each ranging from 0 to 1 inclusive) to a packed
963         * float color in IPT format.
964         * @param hue hue, from 0 to 1 inclusive; 0 is red, 0.25 is yellow, 0.75 is blue
965         * @param saturation saturation from 0 (grayscale) to a limit between 0 and 1 depending on intensity (it can be 1 only when intensity is 0.5)
966         * @param intensity intensity, or lightness, from 0 (black) to 1 (white)
967         * @param alpha alpha transparency/opacity, from 0 (fully transparent) to 1 (fully opaque)
968         * @return a packed float in IPT format
969         */
970        public static float fromHSI(float hue, float saturation, float intensity, float alpha){
971                final float y = TrigTools.cosTurns(hue) * saturation, z = TrigTools.sinTurns(hue) * saturation;
972                final float crMid = 0.3481738f * y + 0.104959644f * z;
973                final float crScale = (intensity - 0.5f + (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(crMid) >>> 31)) * 0.16420607f / -crMid;
974                final float mgMid = 0.122068435f * y + -0.070396f * z;
975                final float mgScale = (intensity + 0.5f - (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mgMid) >>> 31)) * -0.16136102f / -mgMid;
976                final float ybMid = 0.020876605f * y + -0.26078433f * z;
977                final float ybScale = (intensity - 0.5f + (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(ybMid) >>> 31)) * 0.16155326f / -ybMid;
978                final float scale = Math.max(crScale, Math.max(mgScale, ybScale));
979                final float d = 4f * saturation * scale / (TrigTools.sin(3.14159f * intensity) + 0.000001f);
980
981                final float p = y * d;
982                final float t = z * d;
983                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int)(alpha * 255) << 24 & 0xFE000000) | ((int) (t * 255) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
984                                | ((int) (p * 255) << 8 & 0xFF00) | ((int) (intensity * 255) & 0xFF));
985        }
986
987        /**
988         * Produces a random packed float color that is always in-gamut (and opaque) and should be uniformly distributed.
989         * @param random a Random object (preferably a subclass of Random, like {@link com.github.tommyettinger.digital.AlternateRandom})
990         * @return a packed float color that is always in-gamut
991         */
992        public static float randomColor(Random random) {
993                final float ir = 0.1882353f, pr = 0.83137256f - 0.5f, tr = 0.6431373f - 0.5f;
994                final float ig = 0.5764706f, pg = 0.12941177f - 0.5f, tg = 0.827451f - 0.5f;
995                final float ib = 0.23137255f, pb = 0.53333336f - 0.5f, tb = 0.02745098f - 0.5f;
996                final float r = random.nextFloat(), g = random.nextFloat(), b = random.nextFloat();
997                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(0xFE000000
998                                | ((int) ((tr * r + tg * g + tb * b) * 128f + 128f) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
999                                | ((int) ((pr * r + pg * g + pb * b) * 128f + 128f) << 8 & 0xFF00)
1000                                | ((int) ((ir * r + ig * g + ib * b) * 256f) & 0xFF));
1001        }
1002
1003        /**
1004         * Produces a random packed float color that is always opaque and should be uniformly distributed.
1005         * This is only present for legacy compatibility; new code should use {@link #randomColor(Random)}.
1006         * @param random a Random object (or preferably a subclass of Random, like {@link com.github.tommyettinger.digital.AlternateRandom})
1007         * @return a packed float color that is always in-gamut
1008         * @deprecated Use {@link #randomColor(Random)} instead.
1009         */
1010        @Deprecated
1011        public static float randomizedColor(Random random) {
1012                final float ir = 0.1882353f, pr = 0.83137256f - 0.5f, tr = 0.6431373f - 0.5f;
1013                final float ig = 0.5764706f, pg = 0.12941177f - 0.5f, tg = 0.827451f - 0.5f;
1014                final float ib = 0.23137255f, pb = 0.53333336f - 0.5f, tb = 0.02745098f - 0.5f;
1015                final float r = random.nextFloat(), g = random.nextFloat(), b = random.nextFloat();
1016                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(0xFE000000
1017                                | ((int) ((tr * r + tg * g + tb * b) * 128f + 128f) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
1018                                | ((int) ((pr * r + pg * g + pb * b) * 128f + 128f) << 8 & 0xFF00)
1019                                | ((int) ((ir * r + ig * g + ib * b) * 256f) & 0xFF));
1020        }
1021
1022        /**
1023         * Limited-use; like {@link #randomColor(Random)} but for cases where you already have three floats (r, g, and b)
1024         * distributed how you want. This can be somewhat useful if you are using a "subrandom" or "quasi-random" sequence,
1025         * like the Halton, Sobol, or R3 sequences, to get 3D points and map them to colors. It can also be useful if you
1026         * want to randomly generate the RGB channels yourself and track the values produced, as you would if you wanted to
1027         * avoid generating too many colors with high blue, for instance. This approximately maps the r, g, and b parameters
1028         * to distances on the RGB axes of a rectangular prism, which is stretched and rotated to form the IPT gamut.
1029         * @param r red value to use; will be clamped between 0 and 1
1030         * @param g green value to use; will be clamped between 0 and 1
1031         * @param b blue value to use; will be clamped between 0 and 1
1032         * @return a packed float color that is always opaque
1033         */
1034        public static float subrandomColor(float r, float g, float b) {
1035                r = Math.min(Math.max(r, 0f), 0.999f);
1036                g = Math.min(Math.max(g, 0f), 0.999f);
1037                b = Math.min(Math.max(b, 0f), 0.999f);
1038                final float ir = 0.1882353f, pr = 0.83137256f - 0.5f, tr = 0.6431373f - 0.5f;
1039                final float ig = 0.5764706f, pg = 0.12941177f - 0.5f, tg = 0.827451f - 0.5f;
1040                final float ib = 0.23137255f, pb = 0.53333336f - 0.5f, tb = 0.02745098f - 0.5f;
1041                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(0xFE000000
1042                                | ((int) ((tr * r + tg * g + tb * b) * 127.5f + 127.5f) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
1043                                | ((int) ((pr * r + pg * g + pb * b) * 127.5f + 127.5f) << 8 & 0xFF00)
1044                                | ((int) ((ir * r + ig * g + ib * b) * 255f) & 0xFF));
1045        }
1046}
